author: sky.cactus
content: This is because gas costs were designed to account for storage tech advancements.  If predictions were accurate, we should predict no increase in gas limit over time. I personally think the projections of disk growth rate were too aggressive, but I know I'm not going to win that battle.

author: ben_a_adams
content:
The issue we are facing is upload speeds for local block building. Downloads are mostly fine and generally ISPs like to pump downloads; however upload speeds don't improve that much and connections are often very asymmetric (like if you want > 50Mbps up; then you probably need 1Gbps down)

So given an increase in blobs/gas; if that's done in one block the upload requirement for the local builder has increased by 100% of that; if its done by increasing blockspeed than that additional upload is shared (assuming the local builder doesn't get two blocks in a row)

author: sky.cactus
content: As a regular human in the real world, I used to be able to run an Ethereum client on my gaming desktop computer, I no longer can and it is because of the disk space requirement.  My computer is used for other things beyond just Ethereum, and I already have multiple 1TB disks that are each over half full.  To run an Ethereum client I would have to buy a dedicated drive, likely 2TB if I don't want to have to replace it soon.  No computer from a big box store (regular consumer hardware) comes off-the-shelf with multiple 2TB drives.

author: sky.cactus
content: I run an Ethereum client on a server, and even with a 2TB drive I am constantly running into problems because the server *also* runs some other stuff and if that other stuff uses any significant amount of disk the drive will fill up.  State pruning has gotten better in clients ,so it doesn't fill up as fast/often, but disk is still the number one problem I run into running Ethereum clients as a non-staker, non-developer (just a user for whom running an Ethereum client shouldn't be a major part of my life).

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the issue is that I'm one of the few remaining people who think that end-users should be able to run their own client.  I get the impression that most core developers these days think clients should be operated by professionals (e.g., stakers, RPC providers, developers) which is why I always butt heads with everyone.

author: marekm3498
content:
Unrelated to gas-limit but related to EIP-4444:

What do others think about starting by removing receipts (for example, pre-merge receipts ~150 GB, all receipts ~209 GB) and agreeing that the torrents solution, together with the ERA format, should be acceptable?

I believe the main concern about using torrents + ERA files for blocks is that we need a strong guarantee to preserve history, which is why we're all working on the Portal Network. However, receipts can be regenerated if we have blocks, so there's no risk of losing them if the blocks are available. This approach could allow us to reduce disk space without waiting for Portal Network integration across all clients. Additionally, it will help the community get used to the idea of removing historical data from nodes.
